Body wall veins and colonic veins
Superior rectal vein and middle rectal vein

questions.text: Which collaterals are responsible for the occurrence of the caput medusae?
questions.solution:
Caput medusa is a manifestation of portal hypertension. Develops as a result of portosystemic anastomosis between umbilical vein and epigastric vein.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1444.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of prehepatic portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of prehepatic portal hypertension is splenic vein thrombosis. This accounts for approximately 50% of cases of portal hypertension in children.

When the portal vein is thrombosed in the absence of liver disease, hepatopetal (to the liver) portal collateral vessels develop to restore portal perfusion. This combination is termed cavernomatous transformation of the portal vein.

The most common cause of intrahepatic presinusoidal hypertension is schistosomiasis.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery 11th edition, Chapter 31, Liver, Pg: 1366.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of isolated splenic vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
• Isolated splenic vein thrombosis (left-sided portal hypertension) is usually secondary to pancreatic inflammation or neoplasm.
  • The result is gastrosplenic venous hypertension, with superior mesenteric and portal venous pressures remaining normal.
  • The left gastroepiploic vein becomes a major collateral vessel, and gastric rather than esophageal varices develop.
  • This variant of portal hypertension is important to recognize because it is easily reversed by splenectomy alone.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1444.

questions.text: Which among the following is the intrahepatic postsinusoidal cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Vascular occlusive disease is an intrahepatic postsinusoidal cause of portal hypertension.


Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 69 : The Liver, Pg: 1203.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of portal hypertension in United States due to secondary deposition of collagen in the space of Disse?
questions.solution:
Alcoholic cirrhosis is the most common cause of portal hypertension overall. It usually causes increased resistance to portal flow at the sinusoidal (secondary to deposition of collagen in the space of Disse) and postsinusoidal (secondary to regenerating nodules distorting small hepatic veins) levels.


Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1445.

choices.text: Diagnosis of the underlying liver disease

questions.text: Which among the following is not an aspect for assessing a patient with suspected chronic liver disease?
questions.solution:
The key aspects for assessing a patient with suspected chronic liver disease or complications of portal hypertension are the following -

  • Diagnosis of the underlying liver disease.
  • Estimation of the functional hepatic reserve- helps to determine whether definitive (e.g., hepatic transplantation) or palliative (e.g., endoscopic variceal ligation or a shunt procedure) treatment is indicated.
  • Definition of portal venous anatomy and hepatic hemodynamic evaluation.
  • Identification of the site of upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, if present.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Chapter 54, Page Number-1445.

questions.text: Which among the following leads to more chances of mortality in patient with oesophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Bleeding from oesophago-gastric varices is the single most life threatening complication of portal hypertension. It is responsible for approximately one third of all deaths in patients with cirrhosis.

The risk for death from bleeding is mainly related to the underlying hepatic functional reserve. Patients with extrahepatic portal venous obstruction and normal hepatic function rarely die of bleeding varices, whereas those with decompensated cirrhosis (e.g., Child-Pugh class C) may face a mortality rate in excess of 50%.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1445.

choices.text: Endoscopic sclerotherapy increases portal venous pressure
Upper GI endoscopy must be performed only after 12 hours of admission
Band ligation is the preferred endoscopic method in control of variceal bleeding
Patient should be stated on vasoactive drugs early to control haemorrhage

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true in the management of oesophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Early upper GI endoscopy, preferably within 12 hours of admission should be done to identify the source of the bleed.

Treatment of oesophageal varices -

  • Resuscitation and stabilisation of the patient with IV fluids, airway protection and oxygen.
  • Consider blood transfusion if haemoglobin falls below 7gm/dl.
  • Start the patient on vasopressins, octreotide to control bleeding. Octreotide is believed to be as effective as endoscopic therapy in controlling bleeding.
  • Early upper GI endoscopy, preferably within 12 hours of admission should be done to identify the source of the bleed.
  • Because infections are common in patients with variceal bleeding, antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated
  • Endoscopic band ligation or sclerotherapy. Band ligation is preferred over sclerotherapy as it has fewer complications. Sclerotherapy, but not band ligation, may increase portal pressures.
  • If they fail - Consider balloon tamponade or TIPS

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1445.

questions.text: Which among the drug is as effective as endoscopic therapy in control of acute variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin and its longer-acting analogue octreotide are as efficacious as endoscopic treatment for control of acute variceal bleeding.

Medical management of variceal bleeding -

  • It works by reducing variceal blood flow, which in turn reduces variceal pressure.
  • Medical therapy should be initiated at the onset of variceal bleeding.
  • Because infections are common in patients with variceal bleeding, antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated. This reduces rebleeding and infection rate, and improves survival.
  • Somatostatin and its longer-acting analogue octreotide are as efficacious as endoscopic treatment for control of acute variceal bleeding.
  • The combination of octreotide and endoscopic therapy is more effective than octreotide alone in controlling bleeding and is the preferred treatment for most patients.
  • In severe cases of hemorrhage, vasopressin (ex: terlipressin) can be used to diminish splanchnic blood flow. It should be given with nitroglycerin simultaneously and then titrated to achieve blood pressure control.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1445.

questions.text: Which stents are recently used in TIPS procedure?
questions.solution:
TIPS(Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt) is a procedure that involves creating a shunt or connection between the portal vein (which carries blood from the intestines to the liver) and one of the hepatic veins (which carries blood away from the liver to the heart). This is done to alleviate complications of portal hypertension, such as esophageal varices.

One of the major complication limiting the usage of TIPS is stent stenosis and stent thrombosis. This is due to intimal hyperplasia of the metallic stent.

Use of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-covered stents helps in overcoming this. PTFE stents have higher patency rates over time and reduced mortality rates.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1446.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions requires emergency surgery in a patient with variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
The most common situations requiring urgent or emergency surgery for the management of variceal bleeding are -

  • Failure of acute endoscopic treatment
  • Failure of long-term endoscopic therapy
  • Hemorrhage from gastric varices or portal hypertensive gastropathy
  • Failure of TIPS placement.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1446.

questions.text: Which among the following pharmacotherapy is very useful in prevention of recurrent variceal haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Nonselective β-adrenergic blockade (propranolol) has shown to significantly decreases the likelihood of recurrent hemorrhage and demonstrates a trend toward decreased mortality.

The combination of a beta blocker and long-acting nitrate (e.g., isosorbide 5-mononitrate) has been shown to be more effective than variceal ligation or beta blockade alone.

Long-term pharmacotherapy should be used only in compliant patients who are observed closely by their physician.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1446.

questions.text: Which among the following procedure for variceal bleeding makes the use of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Sengstaken Blakemore tube. It is used in balloon tamponade for control of variceal hemorrhage.

ADVANTAGES -

  • Immediate cessation of bleeding in more than 85% of patients.
  • Widespread availability of the device.

DISADVANTAGES -

  • Frequent recurrent hemorrhage in up to 50% of patients after balloon deflation.
  • Considerable discomfort for the patient.
  • High incidence of serious complications when it is used incorrectly by an inexperienced healthcare provider.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1446.

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used vessel for the approach to inferior venacava for TIPS procedure in a patient with variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
In Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt (TIPS) placement, the IVC is accessed through right internal jugular vein. If the right internal jugular vein is unsuitable, left internal jugular vein may also be used.

In TIPS, a shunt is created between the intrahepatic branch of the portal vein and a hepatic vein radicle, thus decreasing resistance and decompressing varices. With TIPS, a functional portacaval side-to-side shunt is established.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1447.

questions.text: Identify the procedure in the given diagram for a patient with variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic therapy for variceal haemorrhage includes endoscopic ligation and endoscopic sclerotherapy. The advantages of endoscopic ligation over sclerotherapy include -

  • Lesser rebleeding and mortality rates
  • Fewer sessions needed to complete treatment

The combination of variceal ligation and pharmacotherapy with nonselective beta blockade is more effective than variceal ligation alone.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1447.

questions.text: Which is ideal procedure for oesophageal varices in patients who fail to respond to endoscopic therapy?
questions.solution:
TIPS (Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent) is now the treatment of choice in variceal haemorrhage that has not responded to drug treatment and endoscopic therapy.

The major advantage of TIPS is that it is a nonoperative approach. Thus, it is ideal when only short-term portal decompression is required. TIPS is also effective for the treatment of medically intractable ascites.

COMPLICATIONS -

  • Post shunt encephalopathy
  • Perforation of liver capsule - main early complication of TIPS which can cause fatal intraperitoneal haemorrhage
  • Shunt stenosis secondary to neointimal hyperplasia.
  • Shunt thrombosis

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 69, The Liver, Pg: 1205.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a classification of portosystemic shunts?
questions.solution:
Portosystemic shunts can be classified into -

  • Non selective shunts - completely decompress the portal venous circulation
  • Selective shunts - compartmentalize the portal venous circulation
  • Partial shunts - partially decompress the portal venous circulation

The diversion of portal blood, which contains hepatotropic hormones, nutrients, and cerebral toxins, is also responsible for the adverse consequences of shunt operations, namely, portosystemic encephalopathy and accelerated hepatic failure.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1448.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in a non-selective shunted patients of variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
The most common causes of death in -

  • Medically treated patients - Rebleeding
  • Shunted patients - Accelerated hepatic failure.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1448.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common complication of conventional splenorenal shunt?
questions.solution:
The conventional splenorenal shunt includes -

  • Anastomosis of the proximal splenic vein to the renal vein.
  • Splenectomy is also performed.

Because the smaller proximal rather than the larger distal end of the splenic vein is used, shunt thrombosis is more common after this procedure than after the distal splenorenal shunt.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1449.

questions.text: Which among the following is a selective shunt used for a patient of variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only distal splenorenal shunt is a selective shunt.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 69, The Liver, Pg: 1206.

questions.text: Which among the following collateral vessel is not interrupted in distal splenorenal shunt?
questions.solution:
The distal splenorenal shunt operation has two important components -

  • Anastomosis of the distal end of the splenic vein to the left renal vein.
  • Interruption of all collateral vessels (e.g., left gastric (coronary) vein and gastroepiploic veins) that connect the superior mesenteric vein and gastrosplenic components of the splanchnic venous circulation.

This results in separation of the portal venous circulation into a decompressed gastrosplenic venous circuit and high-pressure superior mesenteric venous system that continues to perfuse the liver.

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver, Pg: 1449.

questions.text: Which among the following is the distal splenorenal shunt?
questions.solution:
The surgical shunt currently used most often is the distal splenorenal or Warren shunt. It has two components -

  • Anastomosis of the distal end of the splenic vein to the left renal vein.
  • Interruption of all collateral vessels (e.g., left gastric (coronary) vein and gastroepiploic veins) that connect the superior mesenteric vein and gastrosplenic components of the splanchnic venous circulation.

Advantages -

  • Lower rate of hepatic encephalopathy and decompensation.
  • Does not interfere with subsequent liver transplantation.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery 11th edition, Chapter 31, Liver, Pg: 1368.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a presenting sign in a patient of Budd-Chiari syndrome?
questions.solution:
Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. Patients may present with -

  • Acute signs and symptoms of abdominal pain
  • Ascites
  • Hepatomegaly

BCS is defined as primary when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venous thrombosis.

BCS is considered as a secondary process when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighbouring lesion originating outside the vein.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery 11th edition, Chapter 31, Liver, Pg: 1368.
